# Day 1280

![Huey Long Smoking On That Free(dom) Money Pack](https://miro.medium.com/1*W9pfDbT1q3YdL0syppXSsw.png)

**When Cotton Got Cheap and Farmers Got Angry**

I was flipping through _Kingfish_ by Richard White, diving into the wild world of Huey Long, Louisiana's one-time governor and professional rabble-rouser, when I hit a story that made me pause mid-sentence. Cotton prices in 1930s Louisiana had tanked, **A LOT**. And farmers? They were _livid_. Not because stuff was too pricey, but because it was too darn cheap. At first, I thought, "What kind of backward logic is this?" Who gripes about a sale on shirts, blankets, or, heck, cotton candy? But then it clicked: when your whole life rides on selling cotton, cheap isn't a bargain, it's actually a punch to the gut. Half the price means half your income, while your debts and taxes just sit there, laughing at you like a bad sitcom villain.

This wasn't about lazy farmers whining for a handout. It was about the "economic rug-pull" of getting to good at making something that left folks scrambling. The market was screaming, "Too much cotton, not enough buyers!" The sensible fix? Adapt. Learn new skills, pivot to new industries, maybe weave cotton into something wild like eco-friendly yoga mats. But Huey Long, bless his populist heart, didn't bother with supply-and-demand charts or TED Talks on reskilling. Nah, he went straight for the crowd-pleaser: _stop growing crops_. Limit supply, jack up prices, keep the creaky system chugging along. It's like telling a chef not to cook to make food pricier. Bonkers, right?

From my cozy 2025 perch, with Wi-Fi humming and a cold-brew in hand this morning, Long's plan sounds like economic fan fiction. Ban cotton production for textiles? Tell farmers to sit on their hands? That's not innovation, that's a government-mandated nap. The market was waving a big neon sign: adapt or bust. But here's the kicker: for tenant farmers stuck in Louisiana's debt peonage trap, "adapting" was about as realistic as me winning a marathon against olympian runners. They couldn't just waltz into a coding bootcamp or move to Silicon Valley. No capital, no mobility, no fancy schools. They were cornered, and Huey's megaphone blared, "I see you, and I'm here to help." His ideas were economic duct tape - sloppy, temporary, and bound to fall apart - but they gave desperate folks a flicker of hope when the market offered none.

That's the populist spark. It doesn't catch fire when people are comfy; it blazes when they're trapped, staring down ruin with no way out. Long's crop-killing schemes were like prescribing aspirin for a broken leg, but to farmers drowning in debt, aspirin was better than being ignored. And here's where I get why his rhetoric worked. He didn't lecture about global trade or productivity shifts, he spoke to their pain. Meanwhile, the market's "price signals" were about as helpful as a GPS yelling "recalculate" in the middle of a swamp.

Progress comes not from freezing the economy to protect yesterday's jobs, but from creating conditions where people can shift into tomorrow's. That means education, mobility, freedom, and yes sound money that doesn't twist the rules to favor one class over another.

Farmers in Huey's time didn't have that chance. We do. Let's not waste it.

Study Bitcoin!

9/22/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
